Hyperglycemic (High Blood Sugar)


Hyperglycemia is when a diabetic has too much sugar in their blood. It is also known as a diabetic coma. This is dangerous and you should always call 111 or 999 and say you suspect hyperglycemia.

c1fdbd0c-bd75-425e-a257-cd50769b7fc9.content:
Symptoms can include:

  • warm, dry skin
  • rapid pulse and breathing
  • fruity, sweet breath (like pear drops)
  • extreme thirst
  • drowsiness
  • become unresponsive

The person may also be wearing a medical wristband to tell people they are diabetic in an emergency.

7771b584-b6fb-41d7-999e-b42dc1fd37b0.content:
Hypoglycemic (Low Blood Sugar) 


Hypoglycemia is the medical term for low blood sugar. This can happen to anyone, but it is particularly common (and more serious) in diabetics.

30e035cd-7260-480f-a850-5ffbcdfdd911.content:
Symptoms can include:

  • feeling weak and faint
  • feeling confused
  • fainting and becoming unresponsive
  • being grumpy, or exhibiting irrational behaviour
  • sweating, cold clammy skin
  • rapid pulse / palpitations
  • trembling or shaking

Again, the person may be wearing a medical wristband to tell people they are diabetic in an emergency.

e6400aed-b52d-498a-9b62-bff13ebfce0a.content:
• Incorrect dose of medication
  • Too much sugary or starchy food
  • May be unwell with an infection
e6400aed-b52d-498a-9b62-bff13ebfce0a.title:
What Causes Hyperglycemia?

(High blood sugar)

c7cf9ecc-0815-4081-b91a-0edc387a6979.content:
• Missed meals
  • A lot of exercise
  • Binge drinking
  • After an epileptic fit
c7cf9ecc-0815-4081-b91a-0edc387a6979.title:
What Causes Hypoglycemia?

(Low blood sugar)

274eca46-4377-4547-a7ea-391db04182b0.content:
Hyperclycemic


Hyperglycemia is an emergency and you should always call 112 or 999 and say you suspect hyperglycemia. Keep monitoring their response while you wait for help, and if they become unresponsive, prepare to treat an unresponsive casualty.

7d6e0b74-2e65-4919-aee6-5ab54421eb72.content:
Hypoglycemic

  1. Help the person to sit down
  2. Help the person to take their glucose tablets or gel if they have them
  3. Or, give them a glass of juice, or three teaspoons of sugar, or three sugary sweets jellybabies
  4. Encourage them to rest and monitor their recovery
  5. Encourage them to test their glucose levels if they have a glucose testing kit
  6. If they improve quickly, give them more high energy food like a sandwich or more sweets

If they do not improve and become unresponsive, prepare to treat an unresponsive casualty and do not try to feed them as they may choke. Call 999.
